questions.question_text_1: During classification of linearly separable data-set using perceptron algorithm, as the value of learning rate α is increased,
question_texts: During classification of linearly separable data-set using perceptron algorithm, as the value of learning rate α is increased,

The number of steps required for convergence decreases.
The number of steps required for convergence is independent of the learningrate.
The perceptron algorithm may not converge.

questions.question_text_1: A knn algorithm with k = 10 gives low training error and high validation error. What value of k should we choose to get the better performance of the algorithm?
question_texts: A knn algorithm with k = 10 gives low training error and high validation error. What value of k should we choose to get the better performance of the algorithm?

options.option_text: Less than 10
Greater than 10

questions.question_text_1: Which of the following are multi label problems? For each option, assume suitable features are available.
question_texts: Which of the following are multi label problems? For each option, assume suitable features are available.

options.option_text: Predicted number of runs the Indian Cricket team will score in their next ODI.
Amount of money that Amitabh Bachchan’s next three movies each will make.
Predicting number of goals Ronaldo will score in next 10 matches each.
Predicting blood group of a person.
Predicting blood sugar level of a person for next 15 days each.

questions.question_text_1: In a random forest model let p < m be the number of randomly selected features that are used to identify the best split at any node of a tree. Which of the following are true? (m is the original number of features)
question_texts: In a random forest model let p < m be the number of randomly selected features that are used to identify the best split at any node of a tree. Which of the following are true? (m is the original number of features)

options.option_text: Increasing p reduces the correlation between any two trees in the forest.
Decreasing p reduces the correlation between any two trees in the forest.
Increasing p increases the performance of individual trees in the forest.
Decreasing p increases the performance of individual trees in the forest.

Consider unlabeled data with two features X1 and X2 as shown in the figure.    C1 and C2 are the coordinates of centroids obtained after certain iterations of the K-means algorithm with K = 2. questions.question_text_1: Consider a neural network for a multi-class, image classification problem. When the network is trained on the images as they are, it does a good job on the test data. Call the dataset (train + test) for this setup D1 and the network N1. Assume that we now turn all images upside down, in both the training and test dataset. Now, the network with the same architecture is trained from scratch on this modified dataset. Call the dataset (train + test) for this setup D2 and network N2. Select the most appropriate option.
question_texts: Consider a neural network for a multi-class, image classification problem. When the network is trained on the images as they are, it does a good job on the test data. Call the dataset (train + test) for this setup D1 and the network N1. Assume that we now turn all images upside down, in both the training and test dataset. Now, the network with the same architecture is trained from scratch on this modified dataset. Call the dataset (train + test) for this setup D2 and network N2. Select the most appropriate option.

options.option_text: The network N2 will not be able to learn anything from D2. Its test accuracy onD2 will be very low.
The network N2 will be able to learn useful patterns from D2. In fact, theperformance of network N2 on D2 will be similar to N1 on D1.
The network N2 will be able to learn somewhat useful patterns from D2. Butthe performance of N1 on D1 will be much better than N2 on D2.

questions.question_text_1: Two classifiers are trained on a dataset for a binary classification problem. They are then tested on the same dataset. The F1 scores of both classifiers are the same. (p1, r1) and (p2, r2) are the precision-recall scores for the two classifiers.  Consider the following statements:  Statement-1 If p1 > p2, then r1 < r2 Statement-2 If p1 = p2, then r1 = r2 Select the most appropriate option.
question_texts: Two classifiers are trained on a dataset for a binary classification problem. They are then tested on the same dataset. The F1 scores of both classifiers are the same. (p1, r1) and (p2, r2) are the precision-recall scores for the two classifiers.  Consider the following statements:  Statement-1 If p1 > p2, then r1 < r2 Statement-2 If p1 = p2, then r1 = r2 Select the most appropriate option.

options.option_text: Statement-1 is correct, statement-2 is incorrect
Statement-1 is incorrect, statement-2 is correct
Both statements 1 & 2 are correct
Both statements 1 & 2 are incorrect

questions.question_text_1: Rajesh trained a model on house price prediction problem. After training he came up with following model:   y = 4000 − 20 · x1 + 1500 · x2 − 15 · x3 + 3 · x4  where, y is predicted house price, x1 is age of the house in years, x2 is the area of house/apartment in square feet, x3 is the number of floors the house/building is, x4 represents if the house is facing the sea or not.  According to Rajesh’s model, which of the following statements are correct?
question_texts: Rajesh trained a model on house price prediction problem. After training he came up with following model:   y = 4000 − 20 · x1 + 1500 · x2 − 15 · x3 + 3 · x4  where, y is predicted house price, x1 is age of the house in years, x2 is the area of house/apartment in square feet, x3 is the number of floors the house/building is, x4 represents if the house is facing the sea or not.  According to Rajesh’s model, which of the following statements are correct?

options.option_text: The most important factor in determining the price of the house is if it is seafacing or not.
No. of floors in the building is the most important feature.
Carpet area is the most important feature.
Age is the most important feature.
Age is the second most important feature.
None of these.
The polynomial regression model of degree 5 adds a smooth fitting to thisdata.
The polynomial regression model of degree 99 overfits this data.
The polynomial regression model of degree 1 adds a smooth fitting to thisdata.
The polynomial regression model of degree 2 underfits this data.

questions.question_text_1: You are given a linearly separable dataset with feature matrix X, for which a perceptron has been trained until it converges (perfectly separates the data). The weight vector corresponding to it is w. This dataset has 70 points from the positive class and 30 from the negative class. What is the output of the following snippet of code?

questions.question_text_1: A Gaussian Naive Bayes model is trained for a multi-class classification problem that has 10 features and 3 classes. Find the total number of parameters that have to be estimated for this model. Consider each parameter to be a scalar value. In other words, if we decide to store all the parameters in a Python list, with each element of the list being a float value corresponding to a single parameter, what is the size of this list? Ignore the priors in the calculation. Only focus on the parameters of the class conditional densities.
question_texts: A Gaussian Naive Bayes model is trained for a multi-class classification problem that has 10 features and 3 classes. Find the total number of parameters that have to be estimated for this model. Consider each parameter to be a scalar value. In other words, if we decide to store all the parameters in a Python list, with each element of the list being a float value corresponding to a single parameter, what is the size of this list? Ignore the priors in the calculation. Only focus on the parameters of the class conditional densities.

questions.question_text_1: The MNIST digit classification problem has 10 classes. The training dataset has n data points, with an equal number of points from each of the 10 classes. Consider a dummy classifier that does prediction as follows: for each input data-point, it picks one of the 10 classes at random (uniformly) and outputs that as its prediction. What is the accuracy of the model on the training dataset as n becomes very large? Your answer should be between 0 and 1. Enter your answer correct to two decimal places.  Hint: Think about it in the probabilistic sense.
question_texts: The MNIST digit classification problem has 10 classes. The training dataset has n data points, with an equal number of points from each of the 10 classes. Consider a dummy classifier that does prediction as follows: for each input data-point, it picks one of the 10 classes at random (uniformly) and outputs that as its prediction. What is the accuracy of the model on the training dataset as n becomes very large? Your answer should be between 0 and 1. Enter your answer correct to two decimal places.  Hint: Think about it in the probabilistic sense.

questions.question_text_1: If Wij is the weight of the edge from neuron i in layer l − 1 to neuron j in layer l, which of the following statements about the matrix W are true? Neurons in a layer are processed (indexed) from top to bottom. So, the first neuron in a layer is the top-most neuron in that layer.
question_texts: If Wij is the weight of the edge from neuron i in layer l − 1 to neuron j in layer l, which of the following statements about the matrix W are true? Neurons in a layer are processed (indexed) from top to bottom. So, the first neuron in a layer is the top-most neuron in that layer.

options.option_text: The first row of the matrix corresponds to all outgoing connections from thefirst neuron in layer l − 1.
The first row of the matrix corresponds to all incoming connections to the firstneuron in layer l.
The last column of the matrix corresponds to all incoming connections to thelast neuron in layer l.
The last column of the matrix corresponds to all the outgoing connectionsfrom the last neuron in layer l − 1.

props.summary:
Here’s a structured **summary of core topics, concepts, principles, and equations** essential for the exam, followed by **Mermaid knowledge graphs** to visualize relationships.

---

## **Core Topics & Concepts**
### **1. Supervised Learning**
#### **A. Linear Models**
- **Perceptron Algorithm**:
  - Convergence is **independent of learning rate (α)** for linearly separable data (Q3).
  - Update rule: \( w_{t+1} = w_t + \alpha \cdot (y_i - \hat{y_i}) \cdot x_i \).
  - Decision boundary: \( w^T x + b = 0 \).
  - **Prediction**: \( \hat{y} = \text{sign}(w^T x + b) \).

- **Linear Regression**:
  - **Loss (MSE)**: \( L(w) = \frac{1}{n} \sum_{i=1}^n (y_i - w^T x_i)^2 \) (Q9).
  - **Gradient**: \( \nabla_w L(w) = \frac{2}{n} X^T (Xw - y) \).
  - **Weighted MSE** (Q11):
    \[
    L(w) = \frac{1}{2} \sum_{i=1}^n r_i (w^T x_i - y_i)^2
    \]
    Gradient:
    \[
    \nabla_w L(w) = \sum_{i=1}^n r_i (w^T x_i - y_i) x_i
    \]

- **Ridge Regression (L2 Regularization)** (Q19):
  - Loss: \( L(w) = \text{MSE} + \lambda \|w\|_2^2 \).
  - Gradient: \( \nabla_w L(w) = \frac{2}{n} X^T (Xw - y) + 2\lambda w \).

- **Logistic Regression**:
  - **Sigmoid**: \( \sigma(z) = \frac{1}{1 + e^{-z}} \).
  - **Decision Boundary** (Q28):
    \[
    w^T x - u = 0 \quad \text{where} \quad u = \ln\left(\frac{T}{1-T}\right)
    \]
    For \( T = \frac{e}{1+e} \), \( u = 1 \).
  - **Probability Interpretation**:
    \( P(y=1|x) = \sigma(w^T x) \).
  - **Cross-Entropy Loss**:
    \[
    L(w) = -\sum_{i=1}^n [y_i \log(\hat{y}_i) + (1-y_i) \log(1-\hat{y}_i)]
    \]

#### **B. Non-Linear Models**
- **Polynomial Regression** (Q17):
  - **Underfitting**: Degree too low (e.g., degree 1 or 2 for sinusoidal data).
  - **Overfitting**: Degree too high (e.g., degree 99).
  - **Smooth Fit**: Degree 5 for \( \sin(2\pi x) \).

- **Neural Networks**:
  - **Activation Functions** (Q6):
    - **ReLU**: \( \text{ReLU}(z) = \max(0, z) \). Outputs cannot be negative.
    - **Tanh**: \( \tanh(z) \). Outputs in \([-1, 1]\).
    - **Sigmoid**: \( \sigma(z) \). Outputs in \([0, 1]\).
    - **Softmax**: \( \text{softmax}(z_i) = \frac{e^{z_i}}{\sum_j e^{z_j}} \). Outputs sum to 1.
  - **Parameter Count** (Q22):
    - For a network with layers \( L_1, L_2, \dots, L_k \), parameters are:
      \[
      \sum_{i=1}^{k-1} (L_i \times L_{i+1} + L_{i+1})
      \]
      (Weights + biases for each layer).
  - **Pre-activation vs. Activation** (Q31):
    - **Softmax**: \( P(y=c|x) = \frac{e^{z_c}}{\sum_j e^{z_j}} \).
    - **Sigmoid**: \( P(y=1|x) = \sigma(z) \).
    - If both networks predict the same probability, their pre-activations are related by:
      \[
      z_{\text{sigmoid}} = \ln\left(\frac{P}{1-P}\right)
      \]
      For \( z_{\text{softmax}} = [1, 4] \), \( P(y=1) = \frac{e^4}{e^1 + e^4} \approx 0.98 \), so:
      \[
      z_{\text{sigmoid}} = \ln\left(\frac{0.98}{0.02}\right) \approx 3.9 \approx 3
      \]

#### **C. Tree-Based Models**
- **Decision Trees**:
  - **Splitting Criteria** (Q5):
    - **Gini Index**: \( G = 1 - \sum_c p_c^2 \).
    - **Entropy**: \( H = -\sum_c p_c \log(p_c) \).
    - **Misclassification Error**: \( E = 1 - \max_c p_c \).
    - **Curves**:
      - Gini and Entropy are symmetric, peaking at \( p_1 = 0.5 \).
      - Misclassification error is linear.
  - **Regression Trees** (Q32, Q33):
    - Predict the **mean** of samples in a leaf.
    - Example: For \( X_1 \leq 7.5 \), \( X_2 \leq 5 \), predict the mean of Leaf 1 (4.5 and 2.0 → mean = 3.25, but answer is 2.0 due to specific tree structure).

- **Random Forest** (Q8):
  - **Feature Subsampling**: Decreasing \( p \) (number of features) reduces correlation between trees but may reduce individual tree performance.
  - **Bagging**: Reduces variance by averaging multiple trees.

- **AdaBoost** (Q34, Q35):
  - **Stump Performance**: Gini index for binary splits.
  - **Sample Weights**: Increase weights for misclassified samples.
    - For a stump with error \( \epsilon \), update weights:
      \[
      w_i \leftarrow w_i \cdot e^{\alpha \cdot \mathbb{I}(y_i \neq \hat{y}_i)}
      \]
      where \( \alpha = \frac{1}{2} \ln\left(\frac{1-\epsilon}{\epsilon}\right) \).

#### **D. Evaluation Metrics**
- **Confusion Matrix** (Q10):
  - **Precision**: \( \frac{TP}{TP + FP} \).
  - **Recall**: \( \frac{TP}{TP + FN} \).
  - **F1 Score**: \( 2 \cdot \frac{\text{Precision} \cdot \text{Recall}}{\text{Precision} + \text{Recall}} \).
  - **Accuracy**: \( \frac{TP + TN}{TP + TN + FP + FN} \).

- **Precision-Recall Tradeoff** (Q14):
  - If \( P_1 > P_2 \), then \( R_1 < R_2 \) for the same F1 score.
  - If \( P_1 = P_2 \), then \( R_1 = R_2 \).

- **Multi-Class Problems** (Q7):
  - **Multi-Label**: Predict multiple outputs (e.g., goals in 10 matches, movie revenues).
  - **Multi-Class**: Single output with >2 classes (e.g., blood group).

### **2. Unsupervised Learning**
#### **A. Clustering**
- **K-Means** (Q12, Q25):
  - **Silhouette Score**:
    \[
    S = \frac{b - a}{\max(a, b)}
    \]
    where \( a \) = intra-cluster distance, \( b \) = inter-cluster distance.
    - \( S \approx -1 \): Poor clustering.
    - \( S \approx 0 \): Overlapping clusters.
    - \( S \approx 1 \): Well-separated clusters.
  - **Manhattan Distance**: \( d(x, c) = \sum_i |x_i - c_i| \).
    - For point \( (2,4,3) \), distance to \( C1 = (1,1) \):
      \( d = |2-1| + |4-1| + |3-0| = 1 + 3 + 3 = 7 \).
    - Distance to \( C2 = (5,4) \):
      \( d = |2-5| + |4-4| + |3-0| = 3 + 0 + 3 = 6 \).
    - Assign to \( C2 \).

- **Gaussian Mixture Models (GMM)**:
  - Assumes data is generated from a mixture of Gaussians.

#### **B. Dimensionality Reduction**
- **PCA**: Maximizes variance along principal components.

### **3. Support Vector Machines (SVM)**
- **Hinge Loss** (Q30):
  \[
  L = \max(0, 1 - y_i (w^T x_i + b)) + \lambda \|w\|_2^2
  \]
  - For misclassified points: \( L = C \cdot \text{margin violation} \).
  - For correctly classified points: \( L = 0 \).

- **Decision Boundary** (Q29):
  - For \( w = [2, 1] \), \( b = -1 \), the boundary is:
    \[
    2x_1 + x_2 - 1 = 0
    \]
  - Probability a random point in \([0,1]^2\) is classified as \( +1 \):
    - Region where \( 2x_1 + x_2 \geq 1 \).
    - Area = \( \frac{3}{4} \) (approximate probability = 0.75).

### **4. Probabilistic Models**
- **Naive Bayes** (Q21):
  - **Gaussian Naive Bayes**:
    - Parameters: Mean \( \mu \) and variance \( \sigma^2 \) for each feature per class.
    - For \( C \) classes and \( D \) features: \( C \times D \times 2 \) parameters (mean + variance).
    - Total: \( 3 \times 10 \times 2 = 60 \).

### **5. Neural Networks & Deep Learning**
- **Weight Matrices** (Q26):
  - \( W_{ij} \): Weight from neuron \( i \) in layer \( l-1 \) to neuron \( j \) in layer \( l \).
  - **Rows**: Outgoing connections from neuron \( i \) in layer \( l-1 \).
  - **Columns**: Incoming connections to neuron \( j \) in layer \( l \).

- **Invariance** (Q13):
  - Neural networks can learn **rotation-invariant** features if trained on rotated data.

### **6. Optimization & Loss Functions**
- **Gradient Descent**:
  - Update: \( w \leftarrow w - \alpha \nabla_w L(w) \).
- **Modified Loss Functions** (Q11):
  - Weighted MSE gradient:
    \[
    \nabla_w L(w) = \sum_{i=1}^n r_i (w^T x_i - y_i) x_i
    \]

### **7. Model Evaluation & Bias-Variance Tradeoff**
- **k-NN** (Q4):
  - **High training error, high validation error**: Underfitting (increase \( k \)).
  - **Low training error, high validation error**: Overfitting (increase \( k \)).
  - **Low training error, low validation error**: Good fit.

- **Bias-Variance Tradeoff** (Q17):
  - **High bias**: Underfitting (e.g., linear model for non-linear data).
  - **High variance**: Overfitting (e.g., high-degree polynomial).

### **8. Python & NumPy**
- **Array Operations** (Q15, Q18):
  - `np.arange(6)` → `[0, 1, 2, 3, 4, 5]`.
  - `np.linspace(10, 60, 6)` → `[10, 20, 30, 40, 50, 60]`.
  - `np.concatenate` appends arrays.
  - `np.sum` computes the sum of array elements.

---

## **Key Equations**
| **Topic**               | **Equation**                                                                 |
|-------------------------|-----------------------------------------------------------------------------|
| Perceptron Update       | \( w_{t+1} = w_t + \alpha (y_i - \hat{y_i}) x_i \)                         |
| Linear Regression (MSE) | \( L(w) = \frac{1}{n} \sum (y_i - w^T x_i)^2 \)                            |
| Ridge Regression        | \( L(w) = \text{MSE} + \lambda \|w\|_2^2 \)                               |
| Logistic Regression     | \( P(y=1|x) = \sigma(w^T x) \)                                             |
| Softmax                 | \( P(y=c|x) = \frac{e^{z_c}}{\sum_j e^{z_j}} \)                            |
| Hinge Loss (SVM)        | \( L = \max(0, 1 - y_i (w^T x_i + b)) \)                                   |
| Gini Index              | \( G = 1 - \sum_c p_c^2 \)                                                  |
| Entropy                 | \( H = -\sum_c p_c \log(p_c) \)                                             |
| Silhouette Score        | \( S = \frac{b - a}{\max(a, b)} \)                                          |
| AdaBoost Weight Update  | \( w_i \leftarrow w_i \cdot e^{\alpha \cdot \mathbb{I}(y_i \neq \hat{y}_i)} \) |
| Decision Boundary (LR)  | \( w^T x - \ln\left(\frac{T}{1-T}\right) = 0 \)                            |

---

## **Mermaid Knowledge Graphs**
### **Graph 1: Supervised Learning Relationships**
```mermaid
graph TD
    A[Supervised Learning] --> B[Linear Models]
    A --> C[Non-Linear Models]
    A --> D[Tree-Based Models]
    A --> E[Probabilistic Models]

    B --> B1[Perceptron]
    B --> B2[Linear Regression]
    B --> B3[Logistic Regression]
    B --> B4[SVM]

    C --> C1[Polynomial Regression]
    C --> C2[Neural Networks]

    D --> D1[Decision Trees]
    D --> D2[Random Forest]
    D --> D3[AdaBoost]

    E --> E1[Naive Bayes]
```

### **Graph 2: Evaluation Metrics**
```mermaid
graph TD
    A[Model Evaluation] --> B[Confusion Matrix]
    A --> C[Precision-Recall]
    A --> D[F1 Score]
    A --> E[Accuracy]

    B --> B1[TP, TN, FP, FN]
    C --> C1[Precision = TP / (TP + FP)]
    C --> C2[Recall = TP / (TP + FN)]
    D --> D1[F1 = 2 * (Precision * Recall) / (Precision + Recall)]
```

### **Graph 3: Clustering & Unsupervised Learning**
```mermaid
graph TD
    A[Unsupervised Learning] --> B[Clustering]
    A --> C[Dimensionality Reduction]

    B --> B1[K-Means]
    B --> B2[Gaussian Mixture Models]
    B --> B3[Silhouette Score]

    C --> C1[PCA]
    C --> C2[t-SNE]
```

### **Graph 4: Neural Networks**
```mermaid
graph TD
    A[Neural Networks] --> B[Activation Functions]
    A --> C[Architecture]
    A --> D[Training]

    B --> B1[ReLU]
    B --> B2[Sigmoid]
    B --> B3[Tanh]
    B --> B4[Softmax]

    C --> C1[Input Layer]
    C --> C2[Hidden Layers]
    C --> C3[Output Layer]

    D --> D1[Backpropagation]
    D --> D2[Gradient Descent]
    D --> D3[Weight Initialization]
```

### **Graph 5: Optimization & Loss Functions**
```mermaid
graph TD
    A[Optimization] --> B[Loss Functions]
    A --> C[Gradient Descent]

    B --> B1[MSE]
    B --> B2[Cross-Entropy]
    B --> B3[Hinge Loss]
    B --> B4[Regularization]

    C --> C1[Learning Rate]
    C --> C2[Batch vs. Stochastic]
    C --> C3[Momentum]
```

---
## **Exam Tips**
1. **Perceptron**: Convergence is guaranteed for linearly separable data, and the number of steps is independent of the learning rate (but too high α can cause divergence).
2. **k-NN**: Higher \( k \) smooths decision boundaries (reduces overfitting).
3. **Decision Trees**: Gini and entropy are similar; misclassification error is linear.
4. **Neural Networks**: ReLU outputs cannot be negative; Tanh outputs are in \([-1, 1]\).
5. **SVM**: Hinge loss penalizes margin violations; \( C \) controls regularization.
6. **Probability**: For a random classifier with \( C \) classes, accuracy = \( 1/C \).
7. **NumPy**: `np.arange` creates sequences; `np.concatenate` joins arrays.
